questions.question: What is Agile?
answers: A software development methodology based on iterative development and incremental delivery.
A traditional project management approach.
A fixed and unchangeable plan of software development.
A documentation-driven software development process.

questions.question: What is the primary measure of success in Agile?
answers: Amount of documentation produced.
Number of completed tasks.
Delivery of working software.
Time taken to complete the project.

questions.question: What are user stories in Agile?
answers: Detailed technical specifications of software features.
High-level business requirements of the project.
Descriptions of software features from an end-user perspective.
Test cases for validating software functionality.

questions.question: What is the purpose of iterations in Agile?
answers: To plan the entire project from start to finish.
To deliver a complete software product at once.
To make large-scale software architecture decisions.
To incrementally build and deliver features over time.

questions.question: How does Agile differ from Waterfall in handling project changes?
answers: Agile cannot accommodate changes once the project starts.
Both Agile and Waterfall equally accommodate changes at any stage.
Agile accommodates changes more flexibly throughout the project.
Waterfall is more adaptive to changes than Agile.

questions.question: What role do unit tests play in Agile development?
answers: They are used only at the final stage of development for final verification.
They replace the need for customer feedback in the development process.
They ensure individual components work as intended, facilitating continuous integration.
They are optional and rarely used in Agile development.
